Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 04:57AM - edited May 13, 2008 04:58AM by formygirls Mia, Welcome to this group. The initial days are confusing and it will get better once you have a tx plan. I feel like an old timer and was only diagnosed 02/28. I am 36 with two beautiful girls. Treatment varies for everybody. I am stage IIIB/C and and my tx involves 4 months of chemo and  8 weeks of radiation. Some patients get Herceptin for a year if they are Her2+. You should bring up all pains to my onc. Most of the time it is nothing but it good to tell your onc everything so they can check it out. On your question regarding mast vs lump that will depend on you and your onc and if your surgeon was able to get clean margins. There is no one answer for everyone. In my case I do not have a choice and will be getting a bilat mast after my chemo is completed. Good luck.

Posts.Content: formygirls wrote: I had three scans last week--a PET/CT, CT of abdomen and pelvis and CT of chest last week. Results are bad and confusing. My PET says improvement and reduction in mets in liver, bones, nodes and does not even mention lungs. The two CT's that I read today show progression in lungs and liver and new lesion in hips. Does anyone else have unreliable PETs? I am bummed that Navelbine has not worked. I am meeting with onc on Monday and hopefully she will change chemo. She just sent me an email saying PET looked great but CT was confusing. Confusing? The CT indicates clear progression to me. I am really disappointed as my TMs have dropped, liver function has improved. I had hoped for better results. Navelbine has been very hard on me but I was ok with it if it was working. Now it appears it is not. My left lobe of the liver which was full of cancer is much better but my right lobe which was clean is now filled with cancer also. Lungs are worse. My brain MRI is not for another few weeks so I do not know if brain mets are back but I have started to have headaches again. Well, on to a new treatment with new hope. Thanks for reading. I am just frustrated and down today. Initially diagnosed with triple neg stage 3 bc in Feb 2008. Mets dx in Feb 2012 with change in receptors .Mets to liver, brain, bone, lung and nodes and central nervous system. Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 07:37AM - edited Apr 25, 2012 07:53AM by formygirls I cannot believe that Tina has died. She had not been to the boards this month and I was afraid. Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 09:27AM formygirls wrote:   HER2 Support Group Forums > her2group I do not know how to post links with my ipad yet and was only able to copy the first message from the discussion thread on the site. complete response of leptomeningeal her2+ bc to intrathecal herceptin (case report other than our member Courtney) Complete response in HER2+ leptomeningeal carcinomatosis from breast cancer with intrathecal trastuzumab Mafalda Oliveira • Sofia Braga • Jose ́ Lu ́ıs Passos-Coelho • Ricardo Fonseca • Joa ̃o Oliveira Received: 15 February 2011 / Accepted: 16 February 2011 / Published online: 3 March 2011 Ó Springer Science+Business Media, LLC. 2011 M. Oliveira (&) 􏰀 J. L. Passos-Coelho 􏰀 J. Oliveira Medical Oncology Department, Instituto Portugueˆs de Oncologia de Lisboa Francisco Gentil, Rua Professor Lima Basto, 1099-023 Lisbon, Portugal e-mail: mafalda.moliveira@gmail.com S. Braga Instituto Gulbenkian de Cieˆncia, Rua da Quinta Grande, 6, P-2780-156 Oeiras, Portugal R. Fonseca Pathology Department, Instituto Portugueˆs de Oncologia de Lisboa Francisco Gentil, Rua Professor Lima Basto, 1099-023 Lisbon, Portuga BRIEF REPORT Abstract Introduction Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis (LC) is a rare but rapidly fatal event in the natural history of breast cancer [1]. HER2? breast cancer has an increased risk of central nervous system (CNS) metastases [2] but there are little data on LC frequency in these tumors [3]. Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against the extracellular domain of the HER2 receptor, is highly effective in systemic control of HER2? metastatic breast cancer [4] but it is not clear if it can penetrate the intact blood brain barrier (BBB) [5]. We report the case of a patient who received weekly intrathecal (IT) trastuzumab for LC from HER2? breast cancer for 18 months, with impressive neurological benefit. Case report A 40 year-old woman presented in April 2003 with a left- sided cT4bN1M0 estrogen receptor (ER) positive (70% of cells) invasive ductal carcinoma. She received six cycles of neoadjuvant chemotherapy (5-FU 500 mg/m2, epirubicin 100 mg/m. Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against the HER2 receptor, is a major breakthrough in the treat- ment of HER2? breast cancer. However, its high molec- ular weight precludes it from crossing the intact blood– brain barrier, making the central nervous system a sanc- tuary to HER2? breast cancer metastases. We prospec- tively assessed functional outcome and toxicity of administering trastuzumab directly into the cerebrospinal fluid of a patient with leptomeningeal carcinomatosis (LC) and brain metastases from HER2? breast cancer that had already been treated with other intrathecal chemotherapy, with no benefit. Upon signed informed consent, weekly lumbar puncture with administration of trastuzumab 25 mg was begun to a 44 year-old women with metastatic breast cancer (lymph node, bone, lung, and liver involvement) previously treated with tamoxifen, letrozole, anthracy- clines, taxanes, capecitabine, intravenous trastuzumab, and lapatinib. She received 67 weekly administrations of intrathecal trastuzumab with marked clinical improvement and no adverse events. She survived 27 months after LC diagnosis. A complete leptomeningeal response, with no evidence of leptomeningeal metastasis at necropsy, was achieved. We believe that intrathecal trastuzumab admin- istration should be prospectively evaluated to confirm clinical activity and optimize dose, schedule, and duration of treatment. Keywords Intrathecal trastuzumab 􏰀 Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis 􏰀 HER2? breast cancer

Posts.Content: formygirls wrote: I would love advice from stage 4 diabetics. I was dx with mets in feb this year and just last month also became diabetic. I have been on decadron a lot with my txs and the cancer along with decadron has made me diabetic last month. Even without steriods my fasting is around 150 and is 250 to 300 fasting with decadron. My sugars stay in the 250- 350 range all day. My oncs say insulin is too dangerous for me since I do not eat well, have nausea and I take steriods inconsistently. They have put me on metformin and the sugar numbers above are with metformin. They have told me to ignore my sugars as I have bigger problems, the impact of high sugars takes place over long term and I will not be around. I met three oncs and they all said the same thing. Insulin would be dangerous and diabeties was the least of my problems. I am vegetarian and the only thing that I can eat these days is fresh fruit and smoothies. I cannot handle eggs or any protein. Anyway just venting if diabetic veterans have any suggestions on handling decadron or veg protien ideas. I am losing weight as I am scared to eat anything with my sugars being so high. I wish I had not developed a meat aversion during chemo but I just cannot handle meat anymore. I know drs are telling to ignore sugars but it is hard to accept that I will not live long enough to deal with the implications of diabeties even though I know it is true. She tried to reassure me, that we need to compare the new liver MRI to the liver MRI from 2 months ago and not read too much into what the breast MRI says. Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 08:53AM - edited Feb 19, 2012 08:55AM by formygirls I also have two kids, 8 and 10. Maybe the diagnosis is too raw and new, but I do not want to create memories. I would like them to forget me as quickly as possible, so they do not hurt and I do not plan on creating anything for them. Everyone is trying to get me to start something for them and how no one can forget their mom. But for me, if they forget me they will not miss me--that is my logic anyway. I may come around one day but I want everyone to forget me so they can move on with their lives. I wish we could all pretend at home that mommy is away on a LONG business trip  and they did not have to face this reality so young. MY dh will be a great parent but I worry constantly how he will cope on his own. I convince myself everyday that I am not indispensable and my kids will not be the only ones to grow up without their mom. They are great kids. I guess what I grieve most daily is more that I will not be able to see what they become as adults, who they marry etc. This is the hardest part of this journey for me. It hurts to even watch them.

Posts.Content: formygirls wrote: Ladies. I do not know how to ride this roller coaster. Early last month I was dx with extensive mets to lungs, liver, bones and nodes. This was sudden and the extent of mets was very hard to take. I spent all of Feb crying nonstop, but went on disability and started tx. I started an easy chemo Navelbine but am having many s/e. I also had a reaction to the Zometa both times with high fevers. But I was coming to terms with it, my liver numbers began to improve a bit and this forum helped me. I began to hope that I could be one of the lucky ones who get a couple of years. I realize that it could not be much longer since I am hormone negative and will always have chemo.  Then last week I started having non stop headaches. I do not know why--I do have large mouth sores from Navelbine but who knows. With my history, it most likely brain mets. I cannot get myself to get a brain MRI. I have barely come to terms with my existing mets. My brain was the only place left.  I am tired of giving bad news to my family. My chemo will have to stop while I get tx for my brain and then my liver will go haywire. I know I am running ahead without a scan but am unable to stop these thoughts as my head pounds constantly. I know I should get a brain MRI but I cannot bring myself to call my onc. I want to be mentally ready for the next steps. I hate opening my eyes in the morning as I begin to feel my headache again. I wish I could stop tx and end all this but know that I cannot because of my kids. With mets everywhere, I struggle with suffering through tx but know I have to keep trying even if there a small flicker of hope. Left to myself, I know I would get off this train. Sorry for the long post but I needed to vent. I feel like just when I managed to bring myself up, another huge wave is coming again at me. Initially diagnosed with triple neg stage 3 bc in Feb 2008. Mets dx in Feb 2012 with change in receptors .Mets to liver, brain, bone, lung and nodes and central nervous system. Posts.Title: neoadjuvant chemo - but tumor not shrinking? Emma56 carpediempenny

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2008 04:07PM - edited Apr 29, 2008 04:08PM by formygirls An update from me on my neo-adjuvant chemo. I did have my MRI this morning and the MRI shows a partial remission. I still have cancer but the dr said 2/3 of the tumor had shrunk. Instead of a bunch of matted lymph nodes with cancer only one node is still swollen and my chest wall involvement has decreased. My onc said while this was not a complete remission which occurs in 10% of the cases, she was happy with the progress after 4 ac. I am on to the 4 taxol which starts next week and will have surgery after all the chemo is completed. I have mixed feelings about the report--I am grateful that there has been some improvement and some remission but there is still some tumor left. The MRI again found a spot on my liver. The good news is the the spot on the liver has not grown/changed in size in the last two months which the onc feels is a positive sign because if it was cancer the spot would have also reduced in size in response to the chemo but the spot also showed blood vessels which means it is a tumor--hopefully benign.

Posts.Content: formygirls wrote: I am starting my first chemo in a couple of hours--cisplatin+gemzar+zometa. So please send your wishes/prayers/energy along to San Diego to kill everyone of these cancer buggers.  The last 10 days have been a rollercoaster. From no tx because of liver to finally a chance to do some chemo to bring my liver numbers down. I also made a 1 day trip to MDA to meet Dr.Gonzalez there and she agreed with my onc here that right now all trials are out till my liver enzymes do not get normal or close to normal again as >5UL disqualifies you. On a surprising note, I got a call late last night from a friend that also got some of my liver tissue saying it was HER2 positive. I have always been triple negative and this would be good as it might give more options. No news on ER/PR yet. Since it is not official and I have nothing from onc, we are not changing my chemo yet. I get 2 rounds of this chemo and then a PET will decided next steps. I feel like a warrior today going into a battle, which he knows he will lose and die in the end but has to keep up a valiant fight and stay on the ground as long as possible to prevent the enemy from entering the city(I know--it sounds silly). So it is with mixed emotions I enter the battleground today, knowing I have to fight on for the kiddos. I have never felt as much loved as I do now. I been overwhelmed by the support from our community and friends and family here. I know dh and kids will be taken care of when I am gone.It gives me some peace. I have already assigned duties to my friends-who will help my kids with hw, pick them from school, meet and talk with dh every Friday so he has someone to talk too and they all cry and laugh but agree:) Have a great day. Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 10:48PM formygirls wrote: Thank you all for your good wishes and support. I have had a rough week. On Wed , I had a marathon infusion session of Gemzar, Cisplatin and Zometa that lasted almost 7 hours, got home and woke with a fever of 103. Had to got to ER and spent 8 long hours as they were not willing to let me go because I had received chemo. Came back home at 9:00 in the morning. Since then I have been running high fevers and chills but have no energy to go to ER again. My path report did came back and I changed from triple negative to Her2+. YAY! So I now will get Navelbine and Herceptin every week starting next week instead of the cocktail I was getting. Otherwise, I am ok and with the help of Xanax, Ambien and a host of other such friends get through the days and nights. I still have not gotten a brain MRI even though my dr ordered one. My mets are already everywhere and I am dreading the news that it is in my brain too. I do not have any symptoms but I know they don't always cause symptoms. The last two weeks have been traumatic and I thank you all again for your support.

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 10:28AM - edited Jul 20, 2012 10:33AM by formygirls This is such a hard post. My daughters just turned 8 and 11. My dh and I have had extensive talks with time about my disease and death. Because of the extent of my disease, we have been very open with them that this is probably the last summer. I have practically working with on who will pick them up for school, help them with prom clothes, who will call dh every evening to remind him to come home, my best friednd will help with homework etc. I am blessed that my parents came from India and are going to live with my dh and my kids to bring them up. My mom is an angel and is trying her best to fill my shoes per my instructions. She is letting me move in piece knowing there will be someone to watch and raise my kids. My dh is a great husband but he is a workaholic. they cry and then I distract them. This will not get easier till I actually go. There are moments I fantasize that that my PET, CT, BRAIN MRI, SPRINE MRI will also show !NED on the same day and I get a reprieve with no txs for 6 months!!!! One can dream. The plan was initially not to talk unless there was major progression. Or tx change that would everyone. Unfortunately, since my dx in Feb, I have had progression every month and tx has changed so often. So we never got the time to sit, calm down and absorb that things will be ok. Got one news, barely got up and then hit us again. ,

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2013 12:14AM formygirls wrote: I think about this all the time now. So much that this is all I do and have sunk further into depression and anxiety. I have progressed on a lot of chemos and have very few options left. I feel all the doors closing one by one. Some days I am so miserable that I want to go right now and want the bus that goes around killing people to hit me. I dream about a quick, painless death. But I see my kids and I want to live. I am 41 and my kids are still young. I do not know if I will ever be strong enough to stop treatments myself. I will let the onc tell me that there are no more options. The ins and my team of doctors will make the decision when i come to the end of the road. I do not want my kids and family to watch me die a miserable death but some part of me keeps hoping that the next treatment will give me a few more months. I cannot bring myself to say stop even though life sucks. My onc said till my body is healthy enough to take chemo txs she is willing to keep trying. She never gives me false hope and stays away from any prognosis discussion. It helps that she has not given up on me yet. I trust her. I know it is a matter of time but I keep crying for more time even though I know it is pointless. This is such a difficult decision and the last and most important one in my life.

Posts.Content: formygirls wrote: Some background. I have brain mets and got radiosurgery for 9 lesions in May. 2012. Since then I have had a few progressions and my MRI this week showed 5 new lesions in my brain that need to be treated. My treatment team does not want me to get WBR because: 1) rad onc feels they can treat me with radiosurgery again. 2)I also have too much systemic disease and cannot be off chemo for three weeks to get WBR 3)I can do WBR only once and they want to save it till the end 4)I am not in a great physical shape for WBR as I am having a tough time on my chemo of Xeloda, Afinitor, tykerb, Herceptin and Zometa. BUT my ins (CIGNA)has denied me treatment for radiosurgery and will only pay for WBR. They have a lifetime limit of only seven lesions for radiosurgery and they say I have exceeded that. This treatment will cost between $15 and $30,000. My doctors have already appealed and lost. CIGNA is insisting I do WBR if I want treatment but my rad onc is insisting I can get by with radiosurgery and I should keep WBR in my back pocket. My rad doc says tx has to be done in the next two weeks otherwise my MRI and CT will have to repeated. Do you have suggestions for me for appealing this through a state agency or some other option? I live in CA. I would really like to avoid WBR for now. If all fails, we will tap into my life ins or 401k but I hate using money that I would like to leave for my kids. Seriously, this whole thing is a nightmare enough without all this. Thank you for your advise. Initially diagnosed with triple neg stage 3 bc in Feb 2008. Mets dx in Feb 2012 with change in receptors .Mets to liver, brain, bone, lung and nodes and central nervous system. Dx 2/3/2012, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/29 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 10:14PM formygirls wrote: Thank you all for your support. I will go for a second opinion. The results were today from a CT Scan and I have a PET on Monday. My onc is trying to get a biopsy of my lungs or liver next week hoping that my markets may change. I am meeting with my onc on Mon morning and I want to impress upon her that I do not want to give up yet. I like her and know she will support me. I go to amjor cancer center here. When I asked her what we should do next, she mentioned that depended on my goals --was a QOL more imp or was I willing to try to fight with chemo. I am very determined to fight this to the extent I can--especially after reading all the posts in this forum. You have all inspired me to fight. I am encouraging my dh to register here also as he needs strenght. My onc gave me the option of starting chemo right away or waiting for a couple of weeks till my biopsy results come in. I told her I would like to start right away as my liver is in a bad state(my numbers are high and I am running a fever). Is that the right decision? Thank you all. I hope to get to know all of you better in the coming days, months and maybe years.
